content:
|   | Electrostatics | Magnetism  |
| --- | --- | --- |
|  Dipole moment | 1/ε0 | μ0  |
|  Equatorial Field for a short dipole | p | m  |
|  Axial Field for a short dipole | -p/4πε0r3 | -μ0m / 4πr3  |
|  External Field: torque | 2p/4πε0r3 | μ02m / 4πr3  |
|  External Field: Energy | p × E | m × B  |
|   | -p·E | -m·B  |

Example 5.2 Figure 5.4 shows a small magnetised needle P placed at a point O. The arrow shows the direction of its magnetic moment. The other arrows show different positions (and orientations of the magnetic moment) of another identical magnetised needle Q.
summary: The invention and application of the electrostatic analog in magnetism are discussed. The relationship between the dipole moment of an electrostatic system and the magnetic moment of a magnetised needle is analyzed. Comparisons and contrasts between the electric and magnetic systems are provided.
hypothetical_questions: How does the electrostatic analog relate to magnetism?
What are the similarities and differences between the electric and magnetic systems?
What is the role of the dipole moment in both electric and magnetic systems?
